VANILLA_TASKS.name: Support Structure Setup
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Install living support trees (Gliricidia or coconut) or artificial poles with shade cloth providing 50-70% shade. Space supports 2m apart for vine training.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Planting Mix
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Prepare well-draining organic mix: 50% coir peat, 30% aged cow manure, 20% rice hull/perlite. Ensure pH 6.0-7.0 and excellent drainage around support base.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Vine Planting and Initial Training
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Plant 30-40cm vine cuttings with 2-3 nodes at base of support. Position at slight angle toward support. Secure loosely with natural fiber ties.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Establishment Watering
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Water lightly daily to maintain consistent moisture without waterlogging. Use fine mist spray to increase humidity around young vine.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Initial Growth Support
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Guide vine growth along support structure. Tie gently with soft materials every 30cm of growth. Remove any flowering attempts in first 2 years.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Apply balanced organic fertilizer (NPK 10:10:10) 50g per plant monthly. Add 2kg aged compost around base every 3 months during wet season.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Vine Training and Looping
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Once vine reaches 1.5m height, train horizontally and loop down to encourage flowering zones. Maintain vine at manageable height for hand pollination.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Hand Pollination
VANILLA_TASKS.description: During flowering season (March-May), hand pollinate flowers early morning using toothpick to transfer pollen. Each flower is receptive for only 6-8 hours.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Pod Development Monitoring
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Monitor developing pods for proper growth and prevent dropping. Support heavy clusters with soft ties. Pods mature in 8-9 months after pollination.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Vanilla Bean Harvesting
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Harvest beans when tips turn slightly yellow but pods are still firm. Pick individually as they ripen over 2-3 week period.

VANILLA_TASKS.name: Traditional Curing Process
VANILLA_TASKS.description: Begin traditional 6-month curing: blanch in 65°C water for 2 minutes, sweat in wooden boxes for 48 hours, then daily sun-drying and night storage cycles.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Cool Zone Selection and Setup
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Select highest elevation area (>1200m) with morning sun, afternoon shade. Install raised beds 15cm high with excellent drainage using river sand and coir mix.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Soil Mix Preparation
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Prepare specialized mix: 40% river sand, 30% aged compost, 20% coir peat, 10% perlite. pH should be 6.0-7.0 with perfect drainage.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Corm Planting
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Plant dormant corms 10cm deep, 15cm apart during dry season (February-March). Select healthy corms >2.5cm diameter for best results.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Dormancy Period Care
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Keep soil barely moist during dormancy. Ensure no waterlogging. Provide shade cloth during hottest months to prevent overheating.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Growth Period Watering
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Increase watering frequency as leaves emerge. Maintain consistent but not excessive moisture. Use drip irrigation or careful hand watering.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Leaf and Flower Bud Monitoring
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Watch for flower bud emergence alongside leaves. Buds appear as purple shoots from soil. Protect from excessive rain during flowering period.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Daily Flower Harvesting
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Harvest flowers at dawn before they fully open. Each flower blooms for only one day. Collect in cool, dry container immediately.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Stigma Extraction
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Within 2 hours of harvest, carefully extract 3 red stigmas from each flower using tweezers. Work in cool, clean environment to preserve quality.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Saffron Drying Process
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Dry stigmas on fine mesh in dark, well-ventilated area for 24-48 hours until crisp. Alternatively, use food dehydrator at 35°C for 4-6 hours.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Corm Care
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Continue care of leaves until they yellow naturally. This feeds the corm for next season. Gradually reduce watering as leaves die back.

SAFFRON_TASKS.name: Storage and Quality Control
SAFFRON_TASKS.description: Store dried saffron in airtight containers away from light and moisture. Label with harvest date. Test quality by color, aroma, and flavor intensity.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Support Tree Installation
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Plant or select living support trees (coconut, jackfruit, or Gliricidia) or install 3m concrete/wooden poles. Ensure partial shade and wind protection.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Planting Pit
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Dig 60cm×60cm×60cm pit near support base. Fill with mixture of topsoil, aged compost, and coir peat. Ensure good drainage and pH 5.5-6.5.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Cutting Planting
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Plant rooted cuttings (3-4 nodes) 30cm from support base during onset of wet season. Position at slight angle toward support structure.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Initial Establishment Care
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Water daily for first month, maintaining consistent soil moisture. Mulch around base with coconut husk or leaves to retain moisture.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Training and Support
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Guide vines to climb support structure. Tie gently with natural materials. Allow main vine to grow vertically, manage lateral branches for fruit production.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Apply 2kg aged cattle manure + 200g bone meal around base every 3 months. Add liquid organic fertilizer (compost tea) monthly during growing season.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Pruning and Vine Management
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Prune excess growth, remove weak branches, and manage vine height at 3-4m for easy harvesting. Remove lower leaves touching ground to prevent disease.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Flowering and Spike Development
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Monitor for flower spikes (appearing 2-3 years after planting). Ensure adequate nutrition and moisture during flowering and fruit development periods.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Green Peppercorn Harvesting
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Harvest pepper spikes when berries are full-size but still green and firm. Pick entire spikes by hand when 1-2 berries start turning red.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Black Pepper Processing
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Remove berries from spikes immediately after harvest. Blanch in boiling water for 1 minute, then sun-dry for 7-10 days until wrinkled and black.

BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Drying and Storage Preparation
BLACK_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Complete drying until moisture content reaches 10-12%. Clean by winnowing, remove light berries and debris. Store in airtight containers.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Shade Structure Setup
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Establish 50-60% shade using live trees (silver oak, albizzia) or shade cloth. Select sloping land at 900-1500m elevation with good air circulation.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Bed Formation
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 30cm high with organic-rich, well-draining soil. Mix forest soil, aged cow dung, and coir peat. Ensure pH 6.0-6.8.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Seedling Transplanting
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Transplant 8-12 month old seedlings during wet season onset. Space 2m×2m apart. Plant at same depth as in nursery, handle root ball carefully.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Establishment Watering
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Water regularly to maintain consistent soil moisture but avoid waterlogging. Use sprinkler or drip irrigation to maintain humidity around plants.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Mulching and Weed Control
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Apply thick mulch (10-15cm) of organic matter around plants. Keep 30cm radius weed-free. Replenish mulch every 3 months.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Program
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Apply NPK organic fertilizer (75:75:150g per plant) in 3 split doses during wet season. Add 10kg aged compost annually around each plant.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Tiller Management
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Remove excess tillers, maintaining 6-8 productive tillers per clump. Remove old, unproductive tillers to encourage new growth and air circulation.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Flowering Spike Monitoring
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Monitor for flowering spikes emerging near plant base (begins 2-3 years after planting). Protect young spikes from soil contact and pests.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Capsule Harvesting
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Harvest capsules when 3/4 mature (green with white lines). Pick by hand every 2-3 weeks during harvest season (October-December).

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Clean harvested capsules immediately. Remove adhering soil and plant matter. Grade by size and quality for different market categories.

CARDAMOM_TASKS.name: Drying and Curing
CARDAMOM_TASKS.description: Dry capsules in specialized drying chambers or clean, ventilated areas. Maintain green color by controlling temperature and humidity. Achieve 10% moisture content.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Support Structure Installation
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Install concrete posts (2.5m high) with cross-arms at top, or use strong wooden poles. Space 2m×3m apart for climbing cactus support.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Well-Draining Soil Preparation
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Prepare elevated planting areas with excellent drainage. Mix equal parts garden soil, compost, and coarse sand. pH should be 6.0-7.0.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Cutting Propagation
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Plant 30-40cm stem cuttings after curing cut ends for 7 days. Plant 10cm deep near support post, ensuring good contact with soil.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Initial Root Development Care
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Water sparingly until roots establish (4-6 weeks). Mist cutting lightly if weather is very dry, but avoid overwatering which causes rot.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Training and Support Attachment
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Guide growing stems to climb support structure. Tie loosely with soft materials. Allow multiple stems to develop for increased production.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Fertilizer Application
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Apply balanced organic fertilizer (NPK 10:10:10) monthly during growing season. Add 2kg compost around base every 3 months.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Pruning and Shape Management
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Prune excess growth to maintain 3-4 main stems per plant. Remove weak, damaged, or overcrowded branches to improve air circulation and light penetration.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Flower Bud Monitoring
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Watch for flower buds forming on mature stems (12-18 months after planting). Buds develop rapidly over 2-3 weeks before night blooming.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Hand Pollination
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Perform hand pollination on night-blooming flowers using paintbrush. Flowers open at night and close by morning - timing is critical for fruit set.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Support
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Support developing fruits with nets or cloth slings to prevent dropping. Fruits mature 30-35 days after pollination, changing color as they ripen.

DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Fruit Harvesting
DRAGON_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Harvest when fruits show color change and slight softness. Cut with sharp knife leaving small stem attached. Handle carefully to avoid damage.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Site Selection and Soil Preparation
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Select well-draining elevated site in up-country wet zone. Dig 1m×1m×1m planting hole, improve drainage with organic matter and sand if needed.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Grafted Tree Planting
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Plant grafted avocado tree during wet season onset. Ensure graft union stays above soil level. Stake young tree for wind protection.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Establishment Watering
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Water deeply twice weekly, ensuring soil drains well between waterings. Maintain consistent moisture without waterlogging during first year.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Young Tree Fertilization
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Apply organic fertilizer monthly: 200g balanced NPK + 2kg compost around tree base. Increase amounts gradually as tree grows.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Pruning and Shape Training
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Prune for central leader system, remove competing leaders and crossing branches. Shape tree for easy harvesting and good air circulation.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Mulching and Weed Control
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Maintain 10cm thick organic mulch around tree base, keeping mulch away from trunk. Control weeds in 2m radius around young tree.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Check regularly for scale insects, mites, and fungal diseases. Inspect leaves, branches, and fruit for signs of problems. Apply organic treatments as needed.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Flowering Period Care
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering (typically 3-4 years after planting). Ensure adequate nutrition and water during bloom. Some varieties may need cross-pollination.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Monitoring
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Monitor fruit development from set to maturity (6-12 months depending on variety). Thin excess fruits if tree is heavily loaded.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Fruit Harvesting
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Harvest mature fruits while still firm (they ripen off tree). Test maturity by picking one fruit and allowing it to ripen for eating quality assessment.

AVOCADO_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Handling
AVOCADO_TASKS.description: Handle harvested fruits carefully to prevent bruising. Store at room temperature to ripen, or refrigerate mature fruits to slow ripening process.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Trellis System Installation
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Install strong trellis system 2m high with T-posts and galvanized wire. Passion fruit vines are heavy when fruiting and need robust support.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Planting
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Plant seedlings or rooted cuttings 3m apart along trellis during wet season. Ensure well-draining soil enriched with compost and organic matter.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Initial Growth Support
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Water regularly maintaining consistent soil moisture. Guide main vine to trellis and tie loosely. Pinch out side shoots until vine reaches trellis height.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Vine Training and Spreading
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Once main vine reaches trellis, allow lateral branches to spread along wires. Train vines to cover trellis evenly for maximum fruiting area.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Regular Fertilization
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Apply balanced organic fertilizer (NPK 12:12:17) monthly. Add 3kg compost around each plant every 3 months during growing season.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Pruning and Maintenance
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Prune excess growth to prevent overcrowding. Remove old, unproductive wood annually. Maintain open canopy for good air circulation and light penetration.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Flowering and Pollination
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering (typically 6-8 months after planting). Most passion fruit varieties are self-pollinating, but hand pollination can increase fruit set.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Care
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Ensure adequate water during fruit development. Fruits mature 70-80 days after flowering. Support heavy fruiting branches to prevent breakage.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Continuous Harvesting
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Harvest ripe fruits that fall naturally or are easily detached. Ripe fruits have wrinkled skin and feel heavy. Harvest 2-3 times per week.

PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
PASSION_FRUIT_TASKS.description: Process fruits immediately for juice extraction or store at room temperature for 1-2 days to enhance flavor. Pulp can be frozen for later use.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Land Preparation and Bed Formation
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 15-20cm high for good drainage. Mix soil with aged cow manure and compost. Ensure well-draining, fertile soil with pH 6.0-7.5.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Rhizome Planting
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Plant seed rhizomes (25-30g pieces with 2-3 buds) 5cm deep, 25cm apart during April-May. Select disease-free, plump mother rhizomes for planting.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Initial Watering and Mulching
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Water lightly after planting, then maintain consistent moisture as shoots emerge (15-20 days). Apply organic mulch to conserve moisture and suppress weeds.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: First Earthing Up
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Perform first earthing up when plants are 25-30cm tall (45-60 days). Add soil around base to encourage rhizome development and provide support.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Apply organic fertilizer: 20g NPK (4:2:6) per plant at 45, 90, and 135 days. Add 1kg aged compost per plant every 2 months during growing season.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Second Earthing Up
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Perform second earthing up at 90 days when plants are well-established. This promotes better rhizome formation and prevents exposure to sunlight.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Weed Management
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Remove weeds regularly, especially during first 4 months. Use hand weeding to avoid damaging shallow rhizomes. Maintain mulch layer.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Irrigation Management
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Maintain consistent soil moisture throughout growing season. Reduce watering 30 days before harvest to improve rhizome quality and storage life.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Disease and Pest Monitoring
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Monitor for leaf spot, rhizome rot, and shoot borer. Check for yellowing leaves or stunted growth. Apply neem-based organic treatments if needed.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Maturity Assessment
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Monitor for senescence signs: yellowing and drying of leaves (7-10 months after planting). This indicates rhizomes are ready for harvest.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Rhizome Harvesting
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Harvest when leaves turn yellow and dry (8-10 months). Dig carefully to avoid damaging rhizomes. Remove soil and separate mother and finger rhizomes.

TURMERIC_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
TURMERIC_TASKS.description: Wash rhizomes thoroughly, boil for 45-60 minutes until tender. Dry in sun for 10-15 days until moisture content reaches 8-10%. Turn regularly during drying.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Dry Zone Site Preparation
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Select well-draining site in dry or intermediate zone. Dig large planting hole 1m×1m×1m. Wood apple tolerates poor soils but benefits from organic amendments.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Seedling or Grafted Plant Establishment
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Plant during early wet season (October-November). Use grafted plants for earlier fruiting or seedlings for longer-term establishment. Space 8m×8m apart.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Drought-Tolerant Establishment
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Water regularly during first year only. Wood apple is extremely drought-tolerant once established. Mulch around base to conserve moisture.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Minimal Fertilization Program
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Apply minimal organic fertilizer: 2kg compost annually. Wood apple thrives in low-fertility conditions and excessive fertilization can reduce fruit quality.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Natural Growth Management
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Allow natural growth pattern with minimal intervention. Remove only dead, diseased, or severely crossing branches. Wood apple has excellent natural form.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Thorns and Safety Management
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Be cautious of sharp thorns during any maintenance work. Consider removing lower thorny branches for easier access, but leave upper canopy intact.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Extended Establishment Period
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Monitor long-term tree development. Wood apple typically takes 5-7 years to start fruiting from seedlings, 3-4 years from grafted plants.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Flowering Period Observation
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Observe flowering which occurs mainly during dry season (February-April). Small, white flowers appear in clusters on branches.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Monitoring
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Monitor fruit development over 10-11 months from flower to maturity. Fruits grow slowly and are ready when they make dull sound when tapped.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Mature Fruit Harvesting
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Harvest mature fruits when shell turns grayish and fruit makes hollow sound when tapped. Use long poles for high fruits due to thorny branches.

WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.name: Traditional Processing
WOOD_APPLE_TASKS.description: Crack hard shell carefully with hammer. Extract pulp for fresh consumption, juice preparation, or traditional medicine. Seeds can be planted for new trees.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Bed Setup
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 15-20cm high for drainage. Mix compost and well-rotted cow dung. Ensure pH 6.0-6.8. Install bamboo stakes for support.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Seed Starting in Nursery
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Sow seeds in seedling trays with coir-compost mix. Keep in shaded area with morning sun. Water gently twice daily.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Transplanting Seedlings
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Transplant 3-week old seedlings (15cm tall) with 4-5 true leaves. Space 45cm apart. Water immediately after transplanting.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Daily Watering
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Water deeply at soil level, avoid wetting leaves. Reduce during monsoon, increase during dry periods. Early morning preferred.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Weekly Weeding and Mulching
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Remove weeds carefully around base. Apply coconut husk or dried grass mulch to retain moisture and suppress weeds.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: First Fertilizer Application
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Apply NPK 10:10:10 (2 tablespoons per plant) mixed with compost. Create shallow furrow around plant base.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Staking and Support
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Tie plants to bamboo stakes using soft cloth strips. Secure main stem and heavy branches to prevent breakage from wind.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Pruning and Suckering
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Remove suckers growing between main stem and branches. Prune lower leaves touching ground. Use clean knife.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Monthly Fertilizing
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Apply balanced fertilizer with extra potassium during fruiting. Include calcium to prevent blossom end rot.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Check for whiteflies, aphids, early blight, and late blight. Inspect undersides of leaves. Use neem oil spray if needed.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Flower and Fruit Monitoring
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Monitor flower sets and fruit development. Hand pollinate if needed during humid periods. Check for fruit cracking.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: First Harvest
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Pick fruits when they start showing color but still firm. Harvest every 2-3 days during peak season.

TOMATO_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Storage
TOMATO_TASKS.description: Store green tomatoes at room temperature to ripen. Ripe tomatoes in cool, dry place for 3-5 days maximum.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Container Setup
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Prepare well-draining soil mix with compost. Use containers minimum 30cm deep or raised beds. Ensure good drainage.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Direct Seeding or Transplanting
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Sow seeds directly 1cm deep or transplant nursery seedlings. Space 30cm apart as cherry tomatoes are more compact.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Daily Light Watering
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Water lightly but consistently. Cherry tomatoes need less water than regular tomatoes but consistent moisture.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Bi-weekly Fertilizing
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Apply diluted liquid fertilizer every two weeks. Cherry tomatoes are heavy feeders but need lighter applications.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Weekly Support and Pruning
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Provide cage or stake support. Minimal pruning required - remove only diseased or damaged branches.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Pest Monitoring
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Monitor for aphids and whiteflies which are attracted to cherry tomatoes. Check fruit for cracking during rain.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Continuous Harvesting
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Pick ripe cherries daily once fruiting begins. Regular picking encourages more production.

CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.name: Fresh Storage
CHERRY_TOMATO_TASKS.description: Store at room temperature for immediate use. Cherry tomatoes have shorter shelf life than regular tomatoes.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Soil Bed Preparation
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Create raised beds with well-draining soil. Mix in aged compost and ensure pH 6.0-7.0. Install drip irrigation if possible.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Seedling Transplantation
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Transplant 6-8 week old seedlings when 10-15cm tall. Space 40cm apart. Plant during cooler part of day.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Daily Watering Routine
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Maintain consistent soil moisture. Capsicum sensitive to both drought and waterlogging. Water at base to avoid fungal issues.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Mulching and Weed Control
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Apply organic mulch around plants. Keep weed-free as capsicum doesn't compete well with weeds.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Balanced Fertilizing
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Apply balanced NPK fertilizer with extra calcium. Avoid high nitrogen which reduces fruiting.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Plant Support Installation
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Install stakes or cages when plants reach 30cm height. Capsicum branches break easily when loaded with fruit.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Flower and Fruit Drop Monitoring
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Monitor for flower drop during extreme heat or heavy rain. Provide shade cloth during intense heat periods.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Check
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Check for aphids, thrips, and bacterial spot. Capsicum susceptible to viral diseases spread by insects.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: First Harvest
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Harvest when fruits reach full size but still green, or wait for color change. Cut with clean knife leaving short stem.

CAPSICUM_TASKS.name: Proper Storage
CAPSICUM_TASKS.description: Store mature green capsicum in cool, humid conditions. Colored peppers have shorter storage life.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation with Drainage
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 20cm high for excellent drainage. Bell peppers very sensitive to waterlogging. Add coarse sand if needed.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Transplanting Quality Seedlings
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Use healthy 8-10 week old seedlings with strong root system. Space 45cm apart for good air circulation.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Careful Daily Watering
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Water consistently but avoid overwatering. Bell peppers need steady moisture but excellent drainage.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Premium Fertilization
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Apply high-quality balanced fertilizer with micronutrients. Bell peppers are heavy feeders requiring consistent nutrition.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Strong Support System
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Install sturdy stakes or tomato cages. Bell peppers become heavy and need strong support to prevent branch breaking.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Climate Protection
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Provide shade cloth during extreme heat and wind protection. Bell peppers sensitive to temperature fluctuations.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Intensive Pest Monitoring
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Check frequently for aphids, spider mites, and caterpillars. Bell peppers attractive to many pests due to tender leaves.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Flower Care and Monitoring
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Monitor flower development and early fruit set. Remove first flowers to encourage plant establishment.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Premium Harvest
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Harvest when peppers reach full size and desired color. Green peppers can be harvested earlier, colored ones for premium price.

BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.name: Quality Storage
BELL_PEPPER_TASKS.description: Handle carefully to avoid bruising. Store in perforated plastic bags in cool area. Maintain high humidity for longer storage.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Deep Soil Preparation
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Prepare deep, well-draining beds with rich organic matter. Eggplants have deep taproot and need loose soil to 45cm depth.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Warm Season Transplanting
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Transplant only when soil temperature consistently above 20°C. Space 60cm apart as eggplants grow large.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Deep Daily Watering
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Water deeply to encourage deep root growth. Eggplants are drought-tolerant once established but need consistent moisture.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Heavy Mulching
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Apply thick layer of organic mulch. Eggplants benefit from soil temperature regulation and moisture retention.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: High Potassium Feeding
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Apply fertilizer high in potassium for fruit development. Include organic compost for sustained nutrition.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Sturdy Plant Support
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Install strong stakes when plants reach 30cm. Eggplants become very heavy and need substantial support.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Flea Beetle Prevention
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Monitor intensively for flea beetles which can devastate young eggplants. Use row covers if necessary.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Monitoring
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Monitor fruit development and remove first few flowers to encourage strong plant establishment.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Regular Harvesting
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Harvest when fruits are glossy and firm but before seeds harden. Cut with knife, don't pull. Wear gloves due to spines.

EGGPLANT_TASKS.name: Immediate Processing
EGGPLANT_TASKS.description: Use eggplants quickly as they don't store well. Can be kept 2-3 days in cool area but quality deteriorates rapidly.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Soil and Trellis Preparation
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Prepare rich, well-draining soil with plenty of compost. Set up trellises or support structures for vertical growing.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Direct Seeding
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Plant seeds directly 2cm deep in warm soil. Space 30cm apart at base of trellis. Plant after last rain of monsoon.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Consistent Daily Watering
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Maintain consistent soil moisture. Cucumbers are 95% water and need steady hydration for quality fruit.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Weekly Vine Training
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Guide vines up trellis weekly. Secure with soft ties. Remove tendrils that wrap around neighboring plants.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Bi-weekly Fertilizing
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Apply balanced fertilizer with extra nitrogen for leaf growth, then switch to higher potassium when flowering begins.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Cucumber Beetle Monitoring
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Check daily for cucumber beetles and bacterial wilt. These are major threats to cucumber crops in tropical climates.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Pollination Assistance
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Monitor flower development. Hand pollinate female flowers with male flowers using small brush during low insect activity.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Daily Harvesting
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Harvest cucumbers daily when 15-20cm long. Regular picking encourages continued production.

CUCUMBER_TASKS.name: Fresh Storage
CUCUMBER_TASKS.description: Store harvested cucumbers in cool, humid conditions. Use within 3-5 days for best quality and crispness.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Inoculation
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Prepare well-draining soil with moderate fertility. Avoid over-fertilizing as beans fix their own nitrogen. Install poles for climbing varieties.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Direct Seeding
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Plant seeds 3cm deep, 15cm apart. For bush beans space in rows, for pole beans plant 6-8 seeds per pole.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Moderate Daily Watering
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Water regularly but avoid overwatering which can cause root rot. Beans prefer slightly dry conditions once established.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Weekly Support for Climbers
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Guide climbing varieties up poles or strings. Secure gently as bean stems are tender and break easily.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Light Weeding
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Keep beds weed-free with shallow cultivation. Bean roots are shallow and can be damaged by deep hoeing.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Minimal Fertilizing
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Apply low-nitrogen fertilizer only if plants show yellowing. Beans produce own nitrogen and excess causes leaf growth over pods.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Pest Monitoring
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Check for aphids, bean beetles, and pod borers. Monitor pods for signs of insect damage.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Regular Harvesting
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Pick pods when young and tender before seeds develop. Harvest every 2-3 days to encourage continued production.

GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.name: Fresh Storage
GREEN_BEANS_TASKS.description: Store fresh beans in perforated plastic bags in cool area. Use within 3-4 days for best quality and tenderness.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Warm Soil Preparation
OKRA_TASKS.description: Prepare well-draining, warm soil with full sun exposure. Okra thrives in hot conditions and needs good drainage.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Seed Soaking and Planting
OKRA_TASKS.description: Soak seeds overnight in warm water to improve germination. Plant 2cm deep, 30cm apart in rows 60cm apart.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Deep Weekly Watering
OKRA_TASKS.description: Water deeply once or twice weekly rather than daily light watering. Okra is drought-tolerant once established.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Regular Weeding
OKRA_TASKS.description: Keep beds weed-free, especially when plants are young. Okra doesn't compete well with weeds initially.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Light Fertilizing
OKRA_TASKS.description: Apply balanced fertilizer monthly. Okra grows in poor soils but produces better with moderate feeding.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Minimal Pest Monitoring
OKRA_TASKS.description: Check for aphids and pod borers. Okra is generally pest-resistant but monitor during flowering and pod development.

OKRA_TASKS.name: Daily Pod Harvesting
OKRA_TASKS.description: Harvest pods daily when 7-10cm long and tender. Regular picking encourages continuous production. Wear gloves due to plant hairs.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Hot Weather Soil Prep
CHILI_TASKS.description: Prepare well-draining soil in full sun location. Chilis need heat and good drainage. Add sand if soil retains too much water.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Transplanting Strong Seedlings
CHILI_TASKS.description: Transplant sturdy seedlings when soil temperature is consistently warm. Space 45cm apart for good air circulation.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Moderate Daily Watering
CHILI_TASKS.description: Water regularly but avoid overwatering. Stressed chili plants often produce hotter peppers.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Light Fertilizing
CHILI_TASKS.description: Apply balanced fertilizer sparingly. Too much nitrogen produces leafy plants with few peppers.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Support Installation
CHILI_TASKS.description: Provide stakes or cages when plants reach 30cm height. Chili branches can break under fruit weight.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Aphid and Mite Monitoring
CHILI_TASKS.description: Check regularly for aphids and spider mites which are common chili pests. Use insecticidal soap if needed.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Flower and Fruit Monitoring
CHILI_TASKS.description: Monitor flower development and early fruit set. Remove first few flowers to encourage plant establishment.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Regular Chili Harvesting
CHILI_TASKS.description: Harvest green chilis when full-sized, or wait for color change for ripe chilis. Cut with knife, don't pull.

CHILI_TASKS.name: Drying and Storage
CHILI_TASKS.description: Dry ripe chilis in sun for long-term storage. Fresh chilis can be stored in refrigerator for 1-2 weeks.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Cool Season Soil Preparation
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Prepare rich, well-draining soil with high organic matter. Plan planting for cooler months in Sri Lanka (November-February).

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Transplanting Quality Seedlings
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Transplant strong, stocky seedlings with 4-5 true leaves. Space 45cm apart to allow for head development.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Consistent Daily Watering
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Maintain consistent soil moisture. Irregular watering causes head splitting and poor quality.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Heavy Fertilizing Program
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Apply nitrogen-rich fertilizer weekly for first month, then balanced fertilizer. Cabbage is a heavy feeder.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Intensive Pest Monitoring
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Check daily for cabbage worms, aphids, and flea beetles. Use row covers or organic pesticides as needed.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Weekly Weeding and Cultivation
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Keep beds completely weed-free. Cultivate shallowly to avoid root damage.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Head Development Monitoring
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Monitor head formation and firmness. Check for signs of bolting during warm weather.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Harvest at Maturity
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Harvest when heads are firm and solid. Cut at base leaving outer leaves. Morning harvest for best quality.

CABBAGE_TASKS.name: Cool Storage
CABBAGE_TASKS.description: Store harvested cabbage in cool, humid conditions. Can keep for several weeks if stored properly.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Cool Weather Soil Preparation
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Prepare extremely rich soil with high nitrogen content. Cauliflower needs perfect conditions and cool weather.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Premium Seedling Transplanting
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Use only the best quality seedlings. Any stress during transplanting can cause poor head formation.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Perfect Daily Watering
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Maintain absolutely consistent soil moisture. Any water stress ruins head development.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Intensive Feeding Program
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Apply high-nitrogen fertilizer weekly, then switch to balanced when heads begin forming.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Climate Protection
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Provide shade cloth during warm periods. Cauliflower extremely sensitive to temperature fluctuations.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Leaf Blanching
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: When heads reach 5cm diameter, tie outer leaves over head to keep white and tender.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Intensive Pest Control
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Monitor constantly for cabbage worms and aphids. Damaged heads are unmarketable.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Head Quality Monitoring
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Check head development daily. Harvest window is very narrow before heads over-mature.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Premium Harvest
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Harvest when heads are compact and white, before they begin to separate. Cut with knife at base.

CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.name: Immediate Processing
CAULIFLOWER_TASKS.description: Use immediately or store in cold, humid conditions. Cauliflower has very short storage life.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Bed Preparation and Soil Mix
GINGER_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 20cm high with excellent drainage. Mix soil with 50% aged organic matter. Ensure loose, friable soil with pH 6.0-6.8 for optimal growth.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Rhizome Selection and Treatment
GINGER_TASKS.description: Select healthy seed rhizomes with prominent buds. Treat with organic fungicide (neem solution) and cure in shade for 24 hours before planting.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Rhizome Planting
GINGER_TASKS.description: Plant seed rhizomes 3-5cm deep, 20-25cm apart during March-May. Place with buds facing upward. Cover lightly with soil and organic mulch.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Germination Care
GINGER_TASKS.description: Keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Shoots emerge 15-20 days after planting. Maintain shade (50%) during initial growth period.

GINGER_TASKS.name: First Earthing Up
GINGER_TASKS.description: Perform first earthing up when shoots are 15-20cm tall. Add soil around base to encourage rhizome development and prevent exposure to light.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Fertilizer Application Schedule
GINGER_TASKS.description: Apply organic fertilizer (NPK 10:5:20) at 30, 60, 90, and 120 days. Add 2kg aged compost per square meter every 6 weeks during growing season.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Second Earthing Up
GINGER_TASKS.description: Perform second earthing up at 90 days when plants are well-established. This is crucial for rhizome quality and prevents greening of rhizomes.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Water Management
GINGER_TASKS.description: Maintain consistent moisture throughout growing season. Water deeply twice weekly, ensuring good drainage. Reduce watering 4 weeks before harvest.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Control
GINGER_TASKS.description: Monitor for shoot borer, scale insects, and soft rot. Check for yellowing or wilting symptoms. Apply neem oil spray and remove affected plants promptly.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Harvest Timing Assessment
GINGER_TASKS.description: Monitor for maturity signs: yellowing and drying of lower leaves (8-10 months after planting). Test dig one plant to check rhizome development.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Fresh Ginger Harvesting
GINGER_TASKS.description: Harvest fresh ginger at 8 months for tender rhizomes, or 10 months for mature ones. Dig carefully with hand fork to avoid damage.

GINGER_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Handling
GINGER_TASKS.description: Clean harvested rhizomes gently, remove soil and roots. For fresh market, wash and air dry. For storage, cure in shade for 3-4 days before storage.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Deep Soil Preparation
CARROT_TASKS.description: Prepare loose, stone-free soil to 30cm depth. Remove all rocks and debris that could cause forked roots.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Fine Seed Sowing
CARROT_TASKS.description: Sow tiny seeds 1cm deep in shallow furrows. Mix with sand for easier sowing. Keep soil moist until germination.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Careful Daily Watering
CARROT_TASKS.description: Water gently to avoid washing away seeds. Use fine spray until seedlings establish.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Seedling Thinning
CARROT_TASKS.description: Thin overcrowded seedlings to 3cm apart when 5cm tall. Overcrowding causes small, malformed roots.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Shallow Weeding
CARROT_TASKS.description: Remove weeds carefully with shallow cultivation. Deep hoeing can damage developing roots.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Light Fertilizing
CARROT_TASKS.description: Apply balanced fertilizer lightly. Too much nitrogen causes leafy growth and poor root development.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Root Fly Monitoring
CARROT_TASKS.description: Check for carrot root fly damage. Use row covers if this pest is problematic in your area.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Root Development Check
CARROT_TASKS.description: Check root development by gently brushing soil away from shoulders. Monitor size and color development.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Harvest at Maturity
CARROT_TASKS.description: Harvest when roots reach desired size and orange color. Lift carefully to avoid breaking.

CARROT_TASKS.name: Storage Preparation
CARROT_TASKS.description: Remove tops and store in cool, humid conditions. Can be stored for several months if conditions are right.

ONION_TASKS.name: Well-Drained Soil Preparation
ONION_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds with excellent drainage and full sun. Onions rot in waterlogged soil.

ONION_TASKS.name: Transplanting or Direct Seeding
ONION_TASKS.description: Transplant seedlings or plant sets 15cm apart in rows. Plant during cool, dry season for best results.

ONION_TASKS.name: Regular Light Watering
ONION_TASKS.description: Water regularly but lightly. Stop watering 2-3 weeks before harvest to allow bulbs to cure.

ONION_TASKS.name: Shallow Cultivation
ONION_TASKS.description: Keep beds weed-free with very shallow cultivation. Onion roots are near surface and easily damaged.

ONION_TASKS.name: Light Nitrogen Feeding
ONION_TASKS.description: Apply light nitrogen fertilizer monthly until bulbs begin swelling, then stop feeding.

ONION_TASKS.name: Thrips Monitoring
ONION_TASKS.description: Check for thrips damage on leaves. These tiny insects can significantly reduce yields.

ONION_TASKS.name: Bulb Development Monitoring
ONION_TASKS.description: Monitor bulb swelling and top development. Healthy tops indicate good bulb formation.

ONION_TASKS.name: Harvest When Tops Fall
ONION_TASKS.description: Harvest when tops fall over and begin drying. Lift carefully and cure in sun for several days.

ONION_TASKS.name: Curing and Storage
ONION_TASKS.description: Cure bulbs in sun until outer skins are papery. Store in cool, dry, well-ventilated area.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Cool Season Soil Preparation
BEETS_TASKS.description: Prepare loose, fertile soil with good drainage. Beets prefer cooler weather and consistent moisture.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Direct Seed Sowing
BEETS_TASKS.description: Sow seeds 2cm deep, 5cm apart. Each 'seed' is actually a cluster, so thinning will be necessary.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Consistent Daily Watering
BEETS_TASKS.description: Maintain consistent moisture for even root development. Irregular watering causes woody, tough roots.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Seedling Thinning
BEETS_TASKS.description: Thin clusters to single strongest seedling when 5cm tall. Use thinned seedlings as microgreens.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Weekly Weeding
BEETS_TASKS.description: Keep beds weed-free, especially when plants are small. Beets don't compete well with weeds.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Balanced Fertilizing
BEETS_TASKS.description: Apply balanced fertilizer monthly. Avoid high nitrogen which promotes leaf growth over root development.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Leaf Miner Monitoring
BEETS_TASKS.description: Check for leaf miner damage on foliage. Remove affected leaves to prevent spread.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Root Size Monitoring
BEETS_TASKS.description: Check root development by gently brushing soil away. Harvest when roots reach desired size.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Successive Harvesting
BEETS_TASKS.description: Harvest roots when 5-7cm diameter. Can harvest leaves earlier for cooking greens.

BEETS_TASKS.name: Fresh Storage
BEETS_TASKS.description: Remove tops and store roots in cool, humid conditions. Use leaves immediately as they don't store well.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Quick Soil Preparation
RADISH_TASKS.description: Prepare loose, well-draining soil quickly. Radishes grow fast and need immediate good conditions.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Direct Seeding
RADISH_TASKS.description: Sow seeds 1cm deep, 3cm apart in rows. Plant small amounts every 2 weeks for continuous harvest.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Daily Light Watering
RADISH_TASKS.description: Water lightly but consistently. Irregular watering causes cracking and hot, woody flavor.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Minimal Thinning
RADISH_TASKS.description: Thin overcrowded seedlings to 5cm apart when first true leaves appear.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Light Weeding
RADISH_TASKS.description: Keep beds weed-free but cultivation should be minimal and shallow.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Minimal Fertilizing
RADISH_TASKS.description: Apply light, balanced fertilizer once if needed. Over-fertilizing causes all leaves and no root.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Flea Beetle Monitoring
RADISH_TASKS.description: Check for flea beetle damage on leaves. Use row covers if damage is severe.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Quick Harvest
RADISH_TASKS.description: Harvest when roots reach desired size, usually 2-4cm diameter. Don't leave too long or they become woody.

RADISH_TASKS.name: Immediate Use
RADISH_TASKS.description: Use radishes immediately for best crispness and mild flavor. Can store in refrigerator for few days.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Rich Soil Preparation
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Prepare very fertile soil with high organic matter. Baby corn needs intensive feeding for rapid growth.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Close Spacing Planting
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Plant seeds 15cm apart in rows 30cm apart. Much closer than regular corn since harvest is early.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Intensive Daily Watering
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Water heavily and consistently. Corn is a water-loving crop and baby corn needs rapid growth.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Heavy Fertilizing
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Apply high-nitrogen fertilizer weekly for rapid vegetative growth needed for early ear production.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Weekly Weeding
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Keep completely weed-free. Corn doesn't compete well with weeds, especially at high density.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Corn Borer Monitoring
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Check for corn borer larvae in stalks and developing ears. Early detection is critical.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Silk Development Monitoring
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Monitor for silk emergence which indicates ears are ready for baby corn harvest.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Early Ear Harvesting
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Harvest ears when silks first appear, before kernels develop. Pick every other day during harvest period.

BABY_CORN_TASKS.name: Immediate Processing
BABY_CORN_TASKS.description: Process baby corn immediately after harvest. Can be blanched and frozen or used fresh within 24 hours.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Cool Season Soil Preparation
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Prepare rich, well-draining soil with high nitrogen content. Plan for coolest part of growing season.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Strong Seedling Transplanting
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Transplant robust seedlings with strong root systems. Space 45cm apart for main head development.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Consistent Daily Watering
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Maintain steady soil moisture. Stress causes premature bolting and poor head formation.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Heavy Nitrogen Feeding
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Apply nitrogen-rich fertilizer weekly for first month, then balanced fertilizer for head development.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Temperature Protection
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Provide shade cloth during warm periods. Broccoli extremely sensitive to heat and will bolt quickly.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Intensive Pest Management
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Monitor daily for cabbage worms, aphids, and flea beetles. Damage to heads makes them unmarketable.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Head Development Monitoring
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Watch head formation carefully. Harvest window is narrow before heads open and flower.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Main Head Harvest
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Cut main head when tight and compact but before flowers open. Leave plant for side shoot development.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Side Shoot Harvesting
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Continue harvesting smaller side shoots for several weeks after main head harvest.

BROCCOLI_TASKS.name: Quick Processing
BROCCOLI_TASKS.description: Use immediately or blanch and freeze. Broccoli deteriorates rapidly and should be processed quickly.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Warm Soil and Space Preparation
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Prepare large planting area with rich, well-draining soil. Each plant needs 1m² space for sprawling growth.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Direct Seeding in Hills
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Plant 2-3 seeds per hill, 3cm deep. Space hills 1m apart. Plant when soil temperature is consistently warm.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Deep Daily Watering
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Water deeply at soil level to avoid wetting leaves. Zucchini needs consistent moisture for continuous production.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Heavy Feeding Program
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Apply high-nitrogen fertilizer bi-weekly. Zucchini are very heavy feeders and need constant nutrition.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Vine Management
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Guide sprawling vines and remove any diseased or damaged leaves. Ensure good air circulation.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Squash Bug Monitoring
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Check daily for squash bugs and cucumber beetles. These pests can devastate zucchini plants quickly.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Pollination Monitoring
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Monitor flower development and pollination. Hand pollinate female flowers if bee activity is low.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Daily Harvesting
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Harvest young zucchini daily when 15-20cm long. Regular harvesting encourages continued production.

ZUCCHINI_TASKS.name: Fresh Use Processing
ZUCCHINI_TASKS.description: Use zucchini fresh immediately or refrigerate for 3-5 days. Can be grated and frozen for later use.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Soil Preparation and Bed Setup
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 15-20cm high with well-draining soil mix. Add compost and ensure pH 5.5-6.5. Create shade structure for 30-40% shade during hot periods.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Planting Strawberry Runners
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Plant healthy runners or seedlings 30cm apart. Ensure crown is at soil level. Water immediately after planting. Best planted during Maha season (Oct-Mar).

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Daily Watering
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Water early morning to keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce during rainy periods. Use drip irrigation if possible.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Weekly Mulching Check
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Maintain organic mulch around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds. Use coconut coir or dried leaves.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Apply compost tea or diluted liquid organic fertilizer. Use NPK 10:10:10 at 5g per plant monthly during growing season.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Runner Management
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Remove excess runners to focus energy on fruit production. Keep 2-3 healthy runners per plant for propagation.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Check for aphids, thrips, and fungal diseases. Look for leaf spots and fruit rot. Apply neem oil spray if needed.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Flower and Fruit Monitoring
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering and fruit development. Remove damaged or diseased fruits. Support heavy fruit clusters.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: First Harvest
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Harvest ripe strawberries when fully red. Pick early morning when cool. Handle gently to avoid bruising.

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Continuous Harvesting
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Regular harvest of ripe fruits every 2-3 days. Peak season harvest during cool months (Dec-Feb).

STRAWBERRY_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
STRAWBERRY_TASKS.description: Sort, clean, and package strawberries immediately. Store in cool, dry place or refrigerate for longer shelf life.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Site Selection and Soil Preparation
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Choose well-drained location with 6+ hours sunlight. Dig holes 60x60x60cm, add compost and ensure good drainage. Space plants 2-3m apart.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Seed Planting or Seedling Transplant
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Plant 3-4 seeds per hole or transplant healthy seedlings. Best time is beginning of Yala season (Apr-May) or Maha season (Oct-Nov).

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Daily Watering (Establishment)
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Water daily for first month, then reduce to every other day. Ensure soil stays moist but not waterlogged.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Regular Watering
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Water 2-3 times per week during dry periods. Increase frequency during flowering and fruiting. Reduce during monsoon.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Seedling Thinning
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: When seedlings are 30cm tall, select strongest plant and remove others. Keep one healthy plant per location.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Apply aged cow manure or compost monthly. Use NPK 14:14:14 at 50g per plant during active growth periods.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Mulching and Weed Control
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Maintain thick mulch layer around base using coconut husks or dried leaves. Remove weeds that compete for nutrients.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Check for papaya fruit fly, aphids, and fungal diseases. Look for papaya ring spot virus symptoms. Apply organic treatments as needed.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Sex Determination and Plant Selection
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Identify plant sex when flowering begins. Keep hermaphrodite plants for best fruit production, remove pure male plants.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Pruning and Maintenance
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Remove dead leaves, damaged fruits, and excess flowers. Prune lower branches to improve air circulation.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: First Fruit Harvest
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Harvest when fruits show yellow color bands. Cut with sharp knife leaving 2cm stem. Handle carefully to avoid bruising.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Continuous Harvesting
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Regular harvest of ripe and semi-ripe fruits. Peak production period with fruits available year-round.

PAPAYA_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
PAPAYA_TASKS.description: Sort fruits by ripeness. Ripen green fruits at room temperature. Process into dried papaya or preserve for value addition.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Site Preparation and Pit Digging
BANANA_TASKS.description: Dig pits 60x60x45cm, space 2m apart. Fill with compost, cow manure, and topsoil. Ensure good drainage and select sunny location.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Sucker Planting
BANANA_TASKS.description: Plant healthy sword suckers or tissue culture plants. Best time is start of monsoon (May-June or Oct-Nov). Plant at same depth as original.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Initial Watering
BANANA_TASKS.description: Water immediately after planting and daily for first two weeks. Ensure soil remains moist during establishment period.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Regular Watering
BANANA_TASKS.description: Water 2-3 times weekly during dry periods. Increase during flowering and bunch development. Reduce during heavy rains.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Mulching Application
BANANA_TASKS.description: Apply thick layer of organic mulch using banana leaves, coconut husks, or dried grass. Maintain throughout growing period.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
BANANA_TASKS.description: Apply aged cow manure or compost every 2 months. Use NPK 100:300:600g per plant at 3, 5, and 7 months after planting.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Sucker Management
BANANA_TASKS.description: Remove excess suckers, keep only 1-2 healthy followers. Select best sucker for next cycle when mother plant fruits.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Weeding and Basin Maintenance
BANANA_TASKS.description: Remove weeds around plants and maintain circular basin for water retention. Avoid disturbing shallow roots.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
BANANA_TASKS.description: Check for nematodes, aphids, and fungal diseases. Monitor for banana bunchy top virus and black sigatoka. Apply organic treatments.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Flowering and Bunch Management
BANANA_TASKS.description: Support heavy bunches with bamboo props. Remove male bud 2 weeks after last female hand appears. Cover bunch with bag.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Pre-Harvest Monitoring
BANANA_TASKS.description: Monitor bunch development and fruit filling. Check for proper finger development and assess harvest timing.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Bunch Harvesting
BANANA_TASKS.description: Harvest when bananas are 3/4 mature (green but well-filled). Cut bunch with sharp knife, handle carefully to avoid damage.

BANANA_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
BANANA_TASKS.description: Separate hands, wash, and ripen in ventilated room. Grade by size and quality. Package for market or process into chips/flour.

LIME_TASKS.name: Site Preparation and Pit Digging
LIME_TASKS.description: Dig pits 1x1x1m, space 3-4m apart. Fill with compost, sand, and topsoil for good drainage. Choose location with morning sun protection.

LIME_TASKS.name: Grafted Sapling Planting
LIME_TASKS.description: Plant grafted saplings during monsoon onset (May or October). Ensure graft union is above soil level. Water immediately after planting.

LIME_TASKS.name: Initial Daily Watering
LIME_TASKS.description: Water daily for first month to establish root system. Apply water slowly around root zone, avoid waterlogging.

LIME_TASKS.name: Regular Watering Schedule
LIME_TASKS.description: Water 2-3 times weekly during dry periods. Increase frequency during flowering and fruit development. Reduce during monsoon.

LIME_TASKS.name: Organic Mulching
LIME_TASKS.description: Maintain organic mulch layer using dried leaves, coconut husks, or grass. Keep mulch away from trunk to prevent pest harboring.

LIME_TASKS.name: Organic Fertilizer Application
LIME_TASKS.description: Apply aged cow manure or compost every 3 months. Use NPK 100:50:120g per year of plant age, split into 3 applications.

LIME_TASKS.name: Training and Pruning
LIME_TASKS.description: Train main branches, remove water shoots and dead wood. Prune for open center to improve air circulation and light penetration.

LIME_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
LIME_TASKS.description: Check for citrus leaf miner, scale insects, and canker disease. Monitor for yellowing leaves indicating nutrient deficiency.

LIME_TASKS.name: Flowering Monitoring
LIME_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering periods (typically 3-4 times per year). Check flower and small fruit drop, ensure adequate nutrition during this period.

LIME_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Monitoring
LIME_TASKS.description: Monitor fruit development and growth. Check for fruit fly damage and fungal infections. Support heavy branches if needed.

LIME_TASKS.name: First Harvest
LIME_TASKS.description: Harvest mature limes when they reach full size but are still green. Pick with short stem attached for longer shelf life.

LIME_TASKS.name: Continuous Harvesting
LIME_TASKS.description: Regular harvest of mature fruits year-round. Peak seasons are typically March-May and September-November in Sri Lanka.

LIME_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
LIME_TASKS.description: Sort limes by size and quality. Store in cool, dry place. Process excess into lime juice or preserve for value addition.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Site Preparation and Soil Amendment
LEMON_TASKS.description: Prepare well-drained soil with pH 6.0-7.0. Dig pits 1x1x1m, add compost and sand. Choose location with protection from strong winds.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Grafted Plant Installation
LEMON_TASKS.description: Plant grafted lemon saplings at beginning of monsoon (May/October). Keep graft union 5cm above soil. Water thoroughly after planting.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Establishment Watering
LEMON_TASKS.description: Water daily for first 6 weeks to establish strong root system. Ensure consistent soil moisture without waterlogging.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Regular Irrigation
LEMON_TASKS.description: Water 3 times weekly during dry season. Increase during flowering and fruit set. Use basin irrigation method around root zone.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Mulch Management
LEMON_TASKS.description: Apply and maintain organic mulch layer. Use coconut coir, dried leaves, or grass clippings. Keep 30cm away from trunk.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Nutritional Feeding Program
LEMON_TASKS.description: Apply organic compost every 3 months. Use balanced NPK fertilizer (10:6:14) at 200g per year of plant age, applied in 3 split doses.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Structural Pruning
LEMON_TASKS.description: Shape tree with open center structure. Remove suckers, dead branches, and crossing limbs. Prune after harvest for best results.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Surveillance
LEMON_TASKS.description: Monitor for citrus black fly, mealybugs, and citrus canker. Check for sooty mold and root rot symptoms. Apply organic controls.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Bloom and Fruit Set Monitoring
LEMON_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering cycles and fruit set percentage. Ensure adequate nutrition and water during critical flowering periods.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Tracking
LEMON_TASKS.description: Track fruit development from set to maturity. Monitor for fruit drop, size development, and pest damage during growth phase.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Mature Fruit Harvesting
LEMON_TASKS.description: Harvest when lemons are fully yellow and firm. Use sharp secateurs to cut with 1cm stem. Handle gently to avoid skin damage.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Ongoing Production Harvest
LEMON_TASKS.description: Continue regular harvesting of mature fruits. Lemons can be harvested year-round with peak production during cool months.

LEMON_TASKS.name: Value Addition Processing
LEMON_TASKS.description: Grade lemons by size and quality. Process into juice, zest, or preserve. Store in cool conditions for extended shelf life.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Site Selection and Soil Preparation
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Select sunny, well-draining location. Dig 60cm×60cm×60cm planting hole. Improve soil with compost and ensure pH 5.5-7.0. Good for dry zone cultivation.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Plant Establishment
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Plant grafted saplings or rooted cuttings during wet season. Space 3m×3m for intensive cultivation. Stake young plants for wind protection.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Initial Growth Care
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Water deeply twice weekly during establishment year. Maintain weed-free circle of 1m radius around young plant. Apply organic mulch.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Young Plant Fertilization
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Apply balanced organic fertilizer monthly: 100g NPK (10:10:10) + 1kg compost per plant. Increase gradually as plant grows larger.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Training and Pruning
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Train to single stem initially, then allow 4-5 main branches. Prune suckers, water shoots, and crossing branches. Shape for easy harvesting.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Mature Tree Fertilization
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Apply organic fertilizer program: 500g NPK + 10kg compost annually. Split applications during flowering and fruit development periods.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Flowering Period Management
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering (typically starts 2-3 years after planting). Ensure adequate water and nutrition during bloom period for good fruit set.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Care
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Monitor developing fruits for proper growth and quality. Thin overcrowded fruits if necessary. Support heavy branches to prevent breakage.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Management
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Monitor for fruit fly, aphids, and bacterial blight. Inspect fruits for cracking and diseases. Apply organic treatments and maintain good sanitation.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Fruit Harvesting
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Harvest fruits when they develop characteristic color and make metallic sound when tapped. Fruits mature 5-6 months after fruit set.

POMEGRANATE_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Handling
POMEGRANATE_TASKS.description: Handle fruits carefully to prevent bruising. Store in cool, dry place. Can be stored for 2-3 months under proper conditions. Grade by size and quality.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Specialized Site Preparation
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Select wet zone lowland location with high humidity and protection from strong winds. Prepare deep, well-draining, organic-rich soil with pH 5.0-6.5.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Shade Structure Installation
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Install 70-80% shade structure for young plants (first 3-5 years). Mangosteen requires protection from direct sunlight during establishment phase.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Seedling Transplanting
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Transplant 2-3 year old seedlings during wet season onset. Handle root system extremely carefully as mangosteen has sensitive tap root.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Intensive Early Care
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Water daily with fine spray to maintain high humidity. Protect from any stress as young mangosteen trees are extremely sensitive to environmental changes.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Organic Matter Application
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Apply aged organic compost monthly around tree base. Mangosteen requires consistent organic nutrition but is sensitive to chemical fertilizers.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Gradual Shade Reduction
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Gradually reduce shade from 80% to 50% over years 3-5, then to 30% for mature trees. This must be done very slowly to avoid shock.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Minimal Pruning
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Perform only essential pruning to remove dead, diseased, or crossing branches. Mangosteen has naturally good shape and excessive pruning delays fruiting.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Long-term Establishment Monitoring
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Monitor tree health and growth progress. Mangosteen is extremely slow-growing and may take 8-12 years to start fruiting from seedling stage.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Flowering Monitoring
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Watch for first flowering (8-12 years after planting). Flowers appear directly on trunk and main branches. Most flowers are female and self-fertile.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Care
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Provide extra nutrition and consistent moisture during fruit development period. Fruits take 3-4 months to mature from flower to harvest.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Premium Fruit Harvesting
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Harvest when fruits turn deep purple and yield slightly to pressure. Handle with extreme care as the skin stains easily and fruits are very valuable.

MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.name: Immediate Premium Processing
MANGOSTEEN_TASKS.description: Process mangosteen immediately after harvest. The fruit deteriorates quickly and must be consumed or sold within 2-3 days of harvest.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Land Preparation and Pit Preparation
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Clear land and dig pits 60x60x60cm, space 3-4m apart. Mix soil with compost and aged manure. Ensure good drainage.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Seedling or Cutting Planting
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Plant healthy seedlings or rooted cuttings at start of monsoon (May/Oct). Plant at same depth as in nursery, water immediately.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Initial Care Watering
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Water daily for first month to ensure establishment. Keep soil consistently moist but avoid waterlogging during establishment.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Regular Watering Regime
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Water 2-3 times per week during dry periods. Increase frequency during flowering and fruit development phases.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Organic Matter Application
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Apply compost or aged cow manure every 3 months. Use NPK 100:50:100g per year of plant age in 3 split applications.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Formative Pruning
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Train young tree with central leader system. Remove low branches, water shoots, and competing leaders for good tree structure.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Weed Control and Mulching
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Remove weeds in 2m radius around tree. Apply organic mulch using dried leaves or coconut husks to retain moisture.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Management
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Monitor for fruit flies, scale insects, and anthracnose disease. Check for wilt symptoms and apply organic treatments as needed.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Flowering Period Monitoring
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Monitor flowering which occurs 2-3 times per year. Ensure adequate nutrition and water during flowering for good fruit set.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Fruit Thinning and Support
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Thin excess fruits when marble-sized to improve fruit quality. Support heavy branches to prevent breakage during fruiting.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: First Harvest
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Harvest fruits when they change from dark green to light green with slight yellow tinge. Handle gently to avoid bruising.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Regular Fruit Harvesting
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Continue harvesting ripe guavas year-round. Peak seasons are typically January-April and July-October in Sri Lanka.

GUAVA_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Handling
GUAVA_TASKS.description: Sort fruits by ripeness and size. Store ripe fruits in cool place. Process into juice, jam, or dehydrated products for value addition.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Site Selection and Preparation
MANGO_TASKS.description: Choose well-drained, sunny location. Dig large pits 1.5x1.5x1m, space 8-10m apart. Fill with compost-enriched soil mix.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Grafted Sapling Planting
MANGO_TASKS.description: Plant grafted mango saplings at monsoon onset (May/October). Keep graft union above soil level. Stake for support if needed.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Establishment Watering
MANGO_TASKS.description: Water deeply twice weekly for first 3 months. Ensure deep root development by watering around entire root zone area.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Growing Season Watering
MANGO_TASKS.description: Water weekly during dry periods. Reduce watering 2 months before expected flowering to stress tree for better flowering.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Annual Organic Fertilization
MANGO_TASKS.description: Apply aged cow manure (20kg) and compost annually. Use NPK 500:250:500g per year of tree age, split into 3 applications.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Structural Training Pruning
MANGO_TASKS.description: Train tree with strong scaffold branches. Remove water shoots, dead wood, and crossing branches. Prune after harvest.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Mulch Circle Maintenance
MANGO_TASKS.description: Maintain 3m diameter mulch circle using organic materials. Keep weeds away and conserve soil moisture around root zone.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
MANGO_TASKS.description: Monitor for mango hoppers, scale insects, anthracnose, and powdery mildew. Apply organic treatments and maintain tree hygiene.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Pre-Flowering Care
MANGO_TASKS.description: Monitor for flower bud formation (typically Dec-Jan). Ensure tree stress through reduced watering to promote flowering.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Flowering and Fruit Set Monitoring
MANGO_TASKS.description: Monitor panicle development and fruit set percentage. Apply balanced fertilizer during flowering for better fruit retention.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Fruit Development Monitoring
MANGO_TASKS.description: Monitor fruit development and check for diseases. Thin fruits if branches are overloaded. Support heavy branches.

MANGO_TASKS.name: First Harvest
MANGO_TASKS.description: Harvest mangoes when they reach maturity (color change, slight softness). Cut with 2cm stem to prevent sap damage.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Annual Harvesting
MANGO_TASKS.description: Continue annual harvest of mature mangoes. Peak season varies by variety but typically March-July in Sri Lanka.

MANGO_TASKS.name: Post-Harvest Processing
MANGO_TASKS.description: Sort mangoes by ripeness and quality. Ripen hard fruits at room temperature. Process into pulp, dried mango, or pickle.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Soil Bed Preparation
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Prepare raised beds 10-15cm high with well-draining, fertile soil. Mix compost and ensure pH 6.0-7.0. Choose location with morning sun, afternoon shade.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Direct Seed Sowing
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Sow seeds 1cm deep, 5cm apart in rows 15cm apart. Plant during cool periods (Nov-Feb) for best results in Sri Lankan climate.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Daily Light Watering
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Water gently twice daily using fine spray. Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Reduce during monsoon periods.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Seedling Thinning
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Thin overcrowded seedlings to 10cm spacing when 5cm tall. Use thinned seedlings as microgreens.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Weekly Fertilizing
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Apply liquid compost tea weekly. Use diluted fish emulsion or NPK 15:15:15 at 5g per square meter.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Pest Monitoring
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Check for aphids, leaf miners, and snails. Use row covers or organic pesticides as needed. Monitor for bolting in hot weather.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Leaf Harvesting
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Harvest outer leaves when 10-15cm long, leaving center to continue growing. Cut in early morning for best quality.

SPINACH_TASKS.name: Fresh Processing
SPINACH_TASKS.description: Wash leaves gently in cool water. Use immediately or store in refrigerator for 3-5 days. Can be blanched and frozen.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Cool Season Soil Preparation
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Prepare loose, fertile soil with excellent drainage. Lettuce needs cool conditions - plan for hill country or cool season growing.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Seedling Transplanting
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Transplant seedlings 20-25cm apart when 4-5 true leaves present. Plant during coolest part of year (Dec-Feb).

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Cool Water Management
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Water with cool water early morning and evening. Maintain consistent moisture without waterlogging.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Shade Protection
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Provide 40-50% shade cloth during hottest parts of day. Essential for successful lettuce growing in tropical climate.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Light Fertilizing
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Apply light, balanced fertilizer bi-weekly. Avoid high nitrogen which causes bitter taste and loose heads.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Pest and Disease Monitoring
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Check for aphids, cutworms, and fungal diseases. Ensure good air circulation to prevent rot.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Head Formation Monitoring
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Monitor head development and check for bolting. Harvest before flowers appear for best quality.

LETTUCE_TASKS.name: Whole Head Harvest
LETTUCE_TASKS.description: Harvest entire head when firm and full-sized. Cut at base in early morning when temperatures are coolest.

KALE_TASKS.name: Rich Soil Preparation
KALE_TASKS.description: Prepare nutrient-rich soil with high organic matter. Kale thrives in cool conditions with consistent moisture and nutrition.

KALE_TASKS.name: Seedling Transplanting
KALE_TASKS.description: Transplant strong seedlings 30cm apart. Plant during cooler months (Nov-Mar) for best leaf quality.

KALE_TASKS.name: Consistent Watering
